title: fa.functional analysis - Minimax theorems in nonconvex setting
body: Let $X$ be a topological space, $Z$ be a compact convex subset of $\mathbb R^m$ , and let $f:X \times Z \to \mathbb R$ be a continuous function (w.r.t the product topology on $X \times Z$ ). Question. Under what minimal additional assumptions do we have the duality $\sup_{z \in Z}\inf_{x \in X}f(x,z) = \inf_{x \in X}\sup_{z \in Z}f(x,z)$ ? The case $m=1$ (in which case $Z$ must be a compact interval in $\mathbb R$ ) was proved in Theorem 1 of Minimax theorems in a fully non-convex setting under additional connectivity conditions on the sets $\arg\min f(\cdot,z)$ and $\arg\max f(x,\cdot)$ for all $(x,z) \in X \times Z$ . fa.functional-analysis convex-optimization convex-analysis Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 3, 2020 at 19:14 asked Jul 3, 2020 at 15:26 dohmatob 7,053 1 1 gold badge 20 20 silver badges 87 87 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 2 $\begingroup$ shouldn't sup and inf be changed on the RHS? $\endgroup$ user35593 –  user35593 2020-07-03 16:44:31 +00:00 Commented Jul 3, 2020 at 16:44 $\begingroup$ Good catch.
